title: Entomologists Require Ethical Guidance for Compassionate Management of Delusional Parasitosis Cases
content: It started with a phone call. By the time I returned from an afternoon field trip, it had become half a dozen phone calls. Soon, I had also received dozens of photographs of “specimens” that included debris, carpet fibers, hair, skin flakes, and scabs, attached to a rapid-fire series of e-mails detailing the nature of a parasitic infestation that the sender was experiencing. In addition to the details of the infestation, the messages were peppered with additional information that helped complete the picture—the sender’s doctor had already dismissed her claims, she had recently experienced significant life changes, and she had several medical conditions and a history of mental health problems.
